introduction.p: In this section, we will study standard examples of constant acceleration such as free flights of projectiles near the surface of the Earth (or any other planet) and boxes sliding frictionlessly on inclined planes.

Constant acceleration means both magnitude and direction of the acceleration vector are unchanging during the interval of interest. If acceleration changes at any instant, we must stop our analysis by constant-accceleration methods at an instant before that happens. For instance, when we are looking at a falling ball, our final instant of time will be the instant before the ball hits the ground. Similarly, when we are tossing a ball, the initial instant will be an instant after the ball has left the hand.

subsection.title: The Plane of Constant Acceleration Motion
subsection.p: Since the direction of acceleration is a special fixed direction in space for a constant acceleration situation, we usually direct one of the Cartesian axes in the direction of the aceleration or exactly opposite to it. This way, you can always have the entire motion in the xy-plane by choosing your x and y axes appropriately as shown in .

This is possible due to the fact that if your a_z = 0 , then v_x and v_z will not change during the motion. Furthermore, if v_z=0 intitially, then it will remain zero and hence z-motion will be trivial, keeping the object confined to the xy-plane.

Even more simplification can occur if we choose the origin of the coordinate system to be the location of the object at the initial instant of interest, making
x_{i} = 0,\ \ y_{i} = 0.

figure.caption: Choosing axes to simplify calculations for constant acceleration motion. (a) Here I have started with the choice of the x axis to be in the direction of the acceleration vector \vec a . (b) The plane formed by the initial velocity \vec v_i and the acceleration \vec a is taken to be the xy-plane.

subsection.title: Constant Acceleration Along x Axis
subsection.p: Suppose an object, say a baseball, is moving at constant acceleration of magnitude a during t=t_i and t=t_f. We wish to address the following question.
If position and velocity at t_i are \vec r_i and \vec v_i , what will be the position and velocity, \vec r_f and \vec v_f , at t_f ?

From our discusssion above, we already, know that we can choose x and y axes so that \vec a and \vec v_i are in the xy-plane. By choosing x to be along the acceleration and origin at the initial position, we will have the following.
\amp \vec a = (a_x, 0) = (a,0) \amp \vec v_i = \left(v_{i,x}, v_{i,y}\right) \amp \vec r_i = (0, 0)
Similarly, we write the position and velocity at final instant in components.
\amp \vec r_f = (x_f, y_f) \amp \vec v_f = \left(v_{f,x}, v_{i,y}\right)
For the same of brevity we also denote the duration t_i to t_f by t rather than \Delta t.
\Delta t = t_f - t_i \equiv t,
For the same reason, we will use a simpler notation for the displacement.
\amp x \equiv \Delta x = x_f - x_i = x_f, \amp y \equiv \Delta y = y_f - y_i = y_f.

Now, collecting x and y components in separate sets along with the time duration, we get two sets of quantities.
\amp x,\ v_{i,x},\ v_{f,x},\ a_x=a,\ t, \amp y,\ v_{i,y},\ v_{f,y},\ a_y=0,\ t.

The x quantities do not depend on the y quantities, and vice-versa, except for the value of time t they share. Furthermore, x quantities are simply one-dimensional constant acceleration motion and y quantities are constant velocity motion. We have already studied them in the context of one-dimensional motions. Therefore, we just summarize the equations we got before.

subsection.title: The Projectile Motion
subsection.p: You have studied what happens in a free fall when you toss a projectile vertically. It just goes up and then comes down with a constant acceleration of magnitude g pointed in straight down direction. When you toss a projectile at an angle, it still has the same acceleration of magnitude g pointed down, but the projectile also moves in the horizontal direction as shown in . This motion is called a projectile motion.

figure.caption: Set up of a projectile motion.

subsection.p: We could choose an axis that has positive x axis down so that a_x = g and a_y = 0. If we do that, we can just use the formulas above for this value of a_x.

However, traditionally, projectile motion is solved using y coordinate pointed up as shown in . This gives us a_x = 0 and a_y = -g, completely switching the roles of x and y axes we used above. Additionally, we get a minus sign. Making these adjustments we get the following formulas, where t=t_f-t_i,\ x=x_f-x_i,\ y=y_f-y_i.

example.title: Constant Acceleration on a Straight Track

statement.p: A runner starts from rest and picks up speed at a constant rate on a straight track. The acceleration has magnitude 1.5\text{ m/s}^2.
(a) What will be his speed 5 seconds later?
(b) How far from the starting place will he be at that time?

solution.title: a
solution.p: This motion is on only one axis. So, let us use x axis for that with the origin at the starting place, and positive x axis pointed in the direction of the runner's motion, which is also the direction of his acceleration here. With this choice, we do not need the axis of the constant velocity motion. We also set t_i = 0 and t_f = t.

With this choice, we have the following values.
a_x = 1.5\text{ m/s}^2,\ \ v_{i,x} = 0, \ \ x_i = 0, \ \ t = 5\text{ s},
and we want to find out v_{f,x} in this part and x_f in the next part. Looking at the list of equations we have, we find the following one to give the answer directly. We omit units in calculations and put them back at the end.
v_{f,x} = v_{i,x} + a_x\, t = 0 + 1.5\times 5 = 7.5\text{ m/s}.

solution.title: b
solution.p:
We don't need to start all over. Plus, we can use the result of part (a) if that is useful. We want x_f. We have some choices in the equations we can use. We omit units in calculations and put them back at the end. Let's use the following equation.
x_f = x_i + v_{i,x}\, t + \frac{1}{2}\, a_x\, t^2,
gives
x_f = 0 + 0 + \frac{1}{2}\times 1.5 \times 5^2 = 18.75\text{ m}.

p.p: A ball is thrown straight up with a speed of 29.43\text{ m/s} . The ball passes a point P that is a height 15 \text{ m} above the launch point twice, once its way up and another time on its way down. Assume free fall, meaning, the accelertion is pointed down with magnitude g or 9.81\text{ m/s}^2.
(a) If the time at the instant of launch has value t=0 , what are the times for the instants when the ball is at P? (b) What are the velocities of the ball when it is at P those two instants?
(c) How high does ball go before returning? (d) How long does it take to get to the highest point?

answer.p: (a) t_1 = 0.56\text{ sec}, t_2 = 5.44\text{ sec} , (b) 23.94\text{ m/s}, -23.94\text{ m/s}, (c) 44\text{ m}, (d) 3.0\text{ sec}.

solution.title: a,b
solution.p: Note that the initial and final points of parts (c) and (d) are different from those of parts (a) and (b). That means we have two separate problems . Lets work out (a) and (b), then we will work out (c) and (d).
We will label quantities with either subscript i or f corresponding to the initial point, i.e. when the ball has left the launcher, or the final point, i.e., when the ball is at point P.

Since only y components are non-zero, we work with y components of all quantities only. We are given:
\amp a_y = -9.81 \text{ m/s}^2,\ \ v_{i,y} = + 29.43\ \text{ m/s} \amp y_i = 0,\ \ y_f = +15.0 \text{ m},\ \ t_i = 0
The following quantities are not known:
t = t_f-t_i,\ \ v_{f,y},
where t will have two values, t_1 and t_2, and v_{f,y} will also have two values, one for going up and one for coming down.

Since the acceleration between t_i and t_f is constant, we use constant-acceleration equations for these components. The following choices are useful.
\amp y_f - y_i = v_{i,y} t + \dfrac{1}{2}\, a_y\, t^2 \amp v_{f,y} = v_{i,y} + a_y t
We will solve Eq. to obtain the times. Putting numerical values in this equation we find that t obeys a quadratic equation, which will have two solutions, corresponding to the two times.
15 - 0 = 29.43\, t + \dfrac{1}{2}\, (-9.81)\, t^2
This gives two answers, t = 0.56, 5.44. Therefore,
\text{(a) }t_1 = 0.56\text{ sec, } t_2 = 5.44\text{ sec}.
(b) Now we use these times to find the v_{f,y} at those instants.
v_{f,y,up} \amp = v_{i,y} + a_y t_1 \amp = 29.43 + (-9.81) \times 0.56 = 23.94\text{ m/s}
v_{f,y,down} \amp = v_{i,y} + a_y t_2 \amp = 29.43 + (-9.81) \times 5.44 = -23.94\text{ m/s}

Two values of v_y ? Note that the only difference between up and down v_y are the sign. When the ball is going up, the direction of the velocity is same as the direction of the positive y axis, while when the ball is coming down, the direction is just the opposite, and hence the minus sign.

solution.title: c,d
solution.p:
Note that at the highest point, v_y = 0. Therefore, taking the launch point as the initial point and the highest point as the final point we have the following knowns:
\amp a_y = -9.81 \text{ m/s}^2,\ \ v_{i,y} = + 29.43\ \text{ m/s} \amp v_{f,y} =0,\ \ y_i = 0, \ \ t_i = 0
The following quantities are not known:
t = t_f-t_i,\ \ y_{f},
where y_f -y_i is the total height the ball flew. We now notice that we can get t from using Eq. , which we can use in the other equation to get y_f .
0 = 29.43 + (-9.81)\, t\ \ \longrightarrow \ \ t = 3.0.
Hence, it takes 3.0\text{ sec} to get to the top of the trajectory. Using this value in Eq. we get
y_f = 0 + 29.43 \times 3.0 + \frac{1}{2}\, (-9.81)\times 3.0^2 = 44.
Therefore, the ball flies to a height of 44\text{ m}.

p.alert: Why is v_y = 0 at the highest point?

solution.p: We notice that just before the ball reaches the highest point, the y component of its velocity (v_y) is positive, but immediartely after the highest point, v_y is negative. Since velocity components must be continuous functions of time (otherwise acceleration will not be defined), the only way they can turn from positive number to negative number is that they go through zero. That means that at the highest point v_y = 0

statement.p: A cannon ball is fired horizontally from a hilltop with a speed of 50\text{ m/s}. The ball lands in the valley after falling a height of 40\text{ m} . Assume free fall.
(a) How far did the ball fly in the horizontal direction?
(b) With what speed did the ball hit the ground?
(c) How long was the ball in the air?

sidebyside.p: The free fall assumption makes it a constant acceleration situation with a = g pointed down. As usual, let positive x be in the horizontal direction towards which the ball flies and positive y vertically up. Let origin be at the starting place, i.e., at the top of the hill - that will make y_f = -h = -40\text{ m}. Let t be the total duration between the initial and final instants.

figure.caption: Set up of a horizontally fired projectile motion.

solution.p:
Using the values above we get the following equations to work with. We omit units in equations, but out them back at the end.
\amp v_{f,x} = v_{i,x} = 50\text{ m/s}, \amp x_f = 50\,t , \amp v_{f,y} = -9.81\, t, \amp -40 = -\dfrac{9.81}{2}\, t^2.

Solving for t we find two values, t = \pm 2.86 , of which only the positive duration is what we want - the negative value refers to a time when the cannon ball would have been at the same height if the trajectory of the ball was exteded back in time. We use the positive time value in other equations to get the other quantities. We now list the answer.
\amp \text{(c) } t = 2.86 \text{ sec}. \amp \text{(a) } x_f = 143 \text{ m}. \amp v_{f,x} = 50\text{ m/s}, \amp v_{f,y} = -28\, \text{ m/s}.
To find the speed of the ball at the final instant before hitting the ground we find the magnitude of the final velocity from the components.
\text{(b) } v = \sqrt{50^2 + 28^2} = 57.3 \text{ m/s}.

example.title: A Projectile Fired at an Angle

statement.p: A cannon ball is fired at a 40^{\circ} above the horizontal direction from a hilltop with a speed of 50\text{ m/s}. The ball lands in the valley after falling a height of 40\text{ m} . Assume free fall.
(a) How far did the ball fly in the horizontal direction?
(b) With what speed did the ball hit the ground?
(c) How long was the ball in the air?

solution.p: I will use the similar setup as in .

sidebyside.p: As usual, let positive x be in the horizontal direction towards the ball flies and positive y vertically up, which makes a_y=-9.81\text{ m/s}^2 and a_x=0. Let origin be at the starting place, i.e., at the top of the hill - that will make y_f = -40\text{ m}. Let t be the total duration between the initial and final instants.

figure.caption: Set up of a projectile fired at an angle from a hilltop.

solution.p:
Using the values above we get the following equations to work with. We omit units in equations, but out them back at the end.
\amp v_{f,x} = v_{i,x} = 38.3\text{ m/s}, \amp x_f = 38.3\,t , \amp v_{f,y} = 32.1-9.81\, t, \amp -40 = 32.1\, t-\dfrac{9.81}{2}\, t^2.
Solving the quadratic equation for t we get two equations, of which we drop the negative time equation.
t = \dfrac{1}{9.81}\left( 32.1 + \sqrt{32.1^2 + 2\times 9.81\times 40} \right) = 7.62\text{ sec}.
Using this we get the x_f and v_{f,y}.
\amp x_f = 38.3\times 7.62 = 292\text{ m}. \amp v_{f,y} = 32.1-9.81\times 7.62 = -42.7\text{ m/s}.
From v_{f,x} and v_{f,y} the speed when the ball hits the ground is v = \sqrt{38.3^2 + 42.7^2} = 57.4\text{ m/s}
Note: This time the ball flew much farther compared to the cannon shot horizontally in .

exercise.title: A Box Sliding Down an Incline with Constant Acceleration

statement.p: Starting from rest a box slides down an incline at a constant acceleration of 2\, \text{m/s}^2 pointed down the incline (not vertically down). (a) Determine the distance traveled on the incline in 1.5\ \text{sec}. (b) Find its speed at t = 1.5\ \text{sec}. (c) Find the average velocity between t = 0 and t =1.5\ \text{sec}. (d) Verify that the displacement during 1.5\ \text{sec} interval from t = 0 to t =1.5\ \text{sec} is equal to the product of average velocity for the interval and the time interval. (e) Will part (d) be true if the acceleration changed with time?

solution.title: a
solution.p:
Let positive x-axis point down the incline. Then, we have
a_x = 2.0\text{ m/s}^2,\ \ v_{0x} =0,\ \ x_0 = 0.
For brevity, drop the subscript x from all our symbols. Then, we will use the following to get x(1.5\text{ s}).
x = x_0 + v_0 t + \frac{1}{2}a t^2 = 0 + 0 + \frac{1}{2}\times 2 \times 1.5^2 = 2.25\,\text{m}.

solution.title: b
solution.p:
Since the motion is only along x-axis, it is sufficient to find v_x (which we will denote by v) to get the speed.
v = v_0 + a t = 0 + 2\times 1.5 = 3.0\,\text{m/s}.
Therefore, speed is |v| = 3.0\,\text{m/s}.

solution.title: c
solution.p:
From positions at t=0 and t=1.5\,\text{m}, we can immediately get v_{av,x}, the average velocity along the x-axis.
v_{av} = \frac{2.25\,\text{m}-0}{1.5\,\text{s}-0} = 1.5\,\text{ m/s}.

solution.title: d
solution.p: Verify it.

solution.title: e
solution.p: Yes, it will still be the case since the average velocity just depends on the displacement divided by time interval. It does not matter whether acceleration was changing or not.

exercise.title: A Hockey Puck Moving up an Incline with a Constant Acceleration

statement.p: A hockey puck is hit up an incline. The puck slows down at a constant acceleration of magnitude 5\, \text{m/s}^2 and stops after 1.2\ \text{sec}. Let x-axis be pointed up the incline. (a) Find the initial velocity, i.e. the velocity of the puck immediately after leaving the stick. (b) How far the puck goes before coming to rest? (c) Find the position of the puck at t = 1\ \text{sec}.

solution.title: a,b
solution.p:
From the description it is clear that while velocity of the puck is up the incline, acceleration is down the incline, since the puck is slowing down. Let us choose positive x-axis pointed up the icline and origin at the place the puck was at t=0. Then, we have
a_y = -5\,\text{m/s}^2,\ \ v_{x}(1.2\,\text{s}) = 0,\ \ x_0=0.
From these, we can find the initial velocity and the total distance moved before coming to rest.
\amp v_0 = v - at = 0 - (-5)(1.2) = 6.0\,\text{m/s} \amp x = x_0 + v_0 t + \frac{1}{2}at^2 = 0 + 6 \times 1.2 + \frac{1}{2}\times (-5)\times 1.2^2 = 3.6\,\text{m}.

solution.title: c
solution.p:
This part has a different interval than parts (a) and (b). However, we can still use the position and velocity at the initial instant and the constant acceleration values from above since they are part of this interval also. Hence, position at t=1\,\text{s} will be
x = x_0 + v_0 t + \frac{1}{2}at^2 = 0 + 6\times 1 + \frac{1}{2}\times (-5)\times 1^2 = 3.5\text{ m}.

statement.p: A football is kicked towards the East. The ball leaves the foot of the kicker at 1.0\text{ m} above ground. At the moment the ball leaves the foot it has a velocity of 22.0\text{ m/s} in 30^{\circ} above the horizontal direction. Ignore effect of air drag on the ball and assume ideal free fall. That is, you can assume that acceleration of the ball has magnitude g and directed Down.
(a) Where on the ground will the ball land?
(b) What will be the be velocity with which the ball will strike the ground?
(c) How long the ball is in the air?

(d) In a coordinate system in which positive x is towards East and positive y is pointed Up, and the origin is at the place where the ball left the kicker, find the path of the ball by giving the function y(x) .

answer.p: (a) 44.27\text{ m}, (b) (19.0\text{ m/s},-11.9\text{ m/s} , or, 22.4\text{ m/s},\ 32^{\circ} clockwise from the forward (i.e., the horizontal) direction, (c) 2.33\text{ sec}, (d) y = 0.58\, x - 0.014\, x^2.

solution.title: (a), (b), and (c)
solution.p: The setup is shown in . As usual, let positive x be in the horizontal direction towards the ball flies and positive y vertically up, which makes a_y=-9.81\text{ m/s}^2 and a_x=0.

sidebyside.p: Let origin be at the starting place, i.e., where the ball leaves the foot giving us y_i=0 and y_f = -1\text{ m}. Let t be the total duration between the initial and final instants.

figure.caption: Set up of a projectile fired at an angle from a hilltop.

solution.p: (a), (b), and (c). Notice the initial instant t_i=0 is the immediate instant after the ball left the foot and the final instant of interest is t_f = t, which is the instant immediately before the ball lands.

The initial velocity is given in the magnitude-direction form. For formulas, we need it in component form.
v_{i,x} \amp = v_i\, \cos\, \theta \amp = 22.0 \times \cos\, 30^{\circ} = 19.0\text{ m/s}. v_{i,y} \amp = v_i\, \sin\, \theta \amp = 22.0 \times \sin\, 30^{\circ} = 11.0\text{ m/s}.
During t=0 to t=t interval, we organize x and y components separately, with the understanding that t is same for both.

Now we will write four equations which can be solved to get the four unknowns here: t,\ x_f,\ v_{f,x},\ v_{f,y} . We will use the following set of equations
v_{f,x} \amp= v_{i,x}, x_f \amp= x_i + v_{i,x}\, t, v_{f,y} \amp= v_{i,y} + a_y\ t, y_f \amp = y_i+ v_{i,y}\, t + \dfrac{1}{2}\, a_y\, t^2.
Putting numerical values (leaving out units) we get
v_{f,x} \amp = 19.0 , x_f \amp = 0 + 19.0\, t, v_{f,y} \amp = 11.0 - 9.81\ t, -1.0 \amp = 0+11.0\, t - \dfrac{1}{2}\times 9.81 \, t^2.
From this list is clear that we solve the last equation for t and use appropriate value in middle two equations to get x_f and v_{f,y} . Note that when we solve the last equation for t , we will get two values, of which we will choose the positive value since, we don't want the time before t = 0. Simplifying we get
4.905\, t^2 - 11\, t - 1 = 0.
This gives
t = \dfrac{1}{9.81}\left( 11 \pm \sqrt{11^2 + 19.62} \right) = -0.1, 2.33.
The value we want is the positive time.
t = 2.33\text{ sec}.
Now we put this value in Eq. and .
\amp x_f = 19.0\times 2.33 = 44.27\text{ m}, \amp v_{f,y} = 11.0 - 9.81\times 2.33 = -11.9\text{ m/s}.
To summarize:
\amp \text{(a) } x_f=44.27\text{ m}, \amp \text{(b) }\vec v_f = (19.0\text{ m/s},-11.9\text{ m/s}), \amp \text{(c) }t = 2.33\text{ sec}.
If interested, one can get final velocity in magnitude-direction form as usual.
v_f = \sqrt{19^2 + 11.9^2} = 22.4\text{ m/s}, \theta = \tan^{-1}\left(\dfrac{-11.9}{19} \right) = -32^{\circ},
which gives the direction to be 32^{\circ} clockwise from the positive x axis in the fourth quadrant, i.e., below the horizontal direction.

solution.title: (d)
solution.p:
Writing x for x_f, y for y_f, and t for t_f, we found the following for x and y of the ball.
\amp x = 19 t, \amp y = 11\, t - 4.905\, t^2.
We can solve the first equation for t and use that in the second equation to get an equation relating x to y .
y = \dfrac{11}{19}\, x - 4.905\times \left( \dfrac{1}{19} \right)^2\, x^2
Simplifying we get the equation of the trajectory to be
y = 0.58\, x - 0.014\, x^2.

exercise.title: The Range and Hang Time of a Projectile

statement.p: A projectile is launched at an angle \theta above the horizontal direction with speed v_0. The projectile lands at the same height after flying freely under gravity with acceleration due to gravity g.
(a) How far will it go in the horizontal direction? This is called range of the projectile.
(b) How long was the ball in the air? This is called the hang time.

hint.p: Set up x and y equations.

solution.p: We use x axis horizontally and y axis vertically up as shown in .

figure.caption: Set up of a projectile fired at an angle.

solution.p:
Let D denote the range and T the hang time. The useful x and y equations are
\amp x\text{-eq: }\ \ D = T\, v_0\,\cos\,\theta, \amp y\text{-eq: }\ \ 0 = T\, v_0\,\sin\,\theta -\dfrac{g}{2}\, T^2,
From the y-eq, we get two values for T.
T = 0,\ \dfrac{2}{g}\,v_0\,\sin\,\theta,
where T=0 is for the starting place and not of interest.
T = \dfrac{2}{g}\,v_0\,\sin\,\theta.
Now, we use this in the x-eqn to get
D = \dfrac{v_0^2}{g}\,\sin\,2\theta.

exercise.title: (Calculus) Practice with a Friend: Range of a Projectile Fired on an Incline

sidebyside.p: A cannon ball is fired up an inclined road as shown in . The initial speed of the ball is fixed at v_0, but its direction can be changed by changing \theta of the the barrel. The projectile lands at a distance D on the incline.

statement.p: (a) Find angle \theta that will give the maximum range, i.e., largest value of D. (b) What is the largest D that can be achieved.
Answer Hint: When \alpha=15^\circ, \theta_\text{max} = 37.5^\circ.

hint.p: Try a coordinate system with x-axis up the incline and y-axis perpendicular to that. This will give you a_x and a_y both non-zero. Also, keep your calculations in v_{0x}, v_{0y}, a_x, and a_y till the end to keep the calcualtion from getting cluttered with too many symbols. Last steps may have tangents and cotangents.
